						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Indonesia</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">

         <th colspan="2"><a href="/wiki/Country_code_top-level_domain" title="Country code top-level domain">Internet TLD</a></th>
         <td><a href="/wiki/.id" title=".id">.id</a></td>
       </tr></table>
<p><b>Indonesia</b> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPAc-en&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPAc-en (page does not exist)">Template:IPAc-en</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Respell&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Respell (page does not exist)">Template:Respell</a> or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPAc-en&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPAc-en (page does not exist)">Template:IPAc-en</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Respell&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Respell (page does not exist)">Template:Respell</a>), officially the <b>Republic of Indonesia</b> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-id&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-id (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-id</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPA-may&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPA-may (page does not exist)">Template:IPA-may</a>), is a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sovereign_state&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sovereign state (page does not exist)">sovereign state</a> in <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oceania" title="Oceania">Oceania</a>. Indonesia is an <a href="/wiki/Archipelago" title="Archipelago">archipelago</a> comprising approximately <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Indonesia" title="List of islands of Indonesia">17,508 islands</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup> It encompasses <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Indonesia" title="Provinces of Indonesia">33 provinces</a> and <a href="/wiki/Special_Region_of_Yogyakarta" title="Special Region of Yogyakarta">1 Special Administrative Region (for being governed by a pre-colonial monarchy)</a> with over 238 million people, making it the world's fourth <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population" title="List of countries by population">most populous</a> country. Indonesia's republic form of government comprises an elected legislature and president. The nation's capital city is <a href="/wiki/Jakarta" title="Jakarta">Jakarta</a>. The country shares land borders with <a href="/wiki/Papua_New_Guinea" title="Papua New Guinea">Papua New Guinea</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=East_Timor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="East Timor (page does not exist)">East Timor</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malaysia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Malaysia (page does not exist)">Malaysia</a>. Other neighboring countries include <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Australia%E2%80%93Indonesia_border&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Australia–Indonesia border (page does not exist)">Australia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Palau" title="Palau">Palau</a>, and the Indian territory of the <a href="/wiki/Andaman_and_Nicobar_Islands" title="Andaman and Nicobar Islands">Andaman and Nicobar Islands</a>. Indonesia is a founding member of <a href="/wiki/Association_of_Southeast_Asian_Nations" title="Association of Southeast Asian Nations">ASEAN</a> and a member of the <a href="/wiki/G-20_major_economies" title="G-20 major economies">G-20 major economies</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Indonesia" title="Economy of Indonesia">Indonesian economy</a> is the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">16th</a> largest by nominal GDP.
</p><p>The Indonesian archipelago has been an important trade region since at least the 7th century, when <a href="/wiki/Srivijaya" title="Srivijaya">Srivijaya</a> and then later <a href="/wiki/Majapahit" title="Majapahit">Majapahit</a> traded with <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> and <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>. Local rulers gradually absorbed foreign cultural, religious and political models from the early <a href="/w/index.php?title=Centuries&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Centuries (page does not exist)">centuries</a> <a href="/wiki/Common_Era" title="Common Era">CE</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Southeast_Asia" title="Hinduism in Southeast Asia">Hindu</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Buddhism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Buddhism (page does not exist)">Buddhist</a> kingdoms flourished. <a href="/wiki/History_of_Indonesia" title="History of Indonesia">Indonesian history</a> has been influenced by foreign powers drawn to its natural resources. <a href="/wiki/Muslim" title="Muslim">Muslim</a> traders brought the now-dominant <a href="/w/index.php?title=Islam_in_Southeast_Asia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Islam in Southeast Asia (page does not exist)">Islam</a>, while European powers brought Christianity and fought one another to monopolize trade in the Spice Islands of <a href="/wiki/Maluku_Islands" title="Maluku Islands">Maluku</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Discovery" title="Age of Discovery">Age of Discovery</a>. Following three and a half centuries of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dutch_East_Indies&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dutch East Indies (page does not exist)">Dutch colonialism</a>, Indonesia <a href="/wiki/Indonesian_National_Revolution" title="Indonesian National Revolution">secured its independence</a> after <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>. Indonesia's history has since been turbulent, with challenges posed by natural disasters, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Corruption_in_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Corruption in Indonesia (page does not exist)">corruption</a>, separatism, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Post-Suharto_era&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Post-Suharto era (page does not exist)">a democratization process</a>, and periods of rapid economic change.
</p><p>Indonesia consists of hundreds of distinct native <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ethnic_groups_in_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ethnic groups in Indonesia (page does not exist)">ethnic</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Languages_of_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Languages of Indonesia (page does not exist)">linguistic groups</a>. The largest &#8211; and politically dominant &#8211; ethnic group are the <a href="/wiki/Javanese_people" title="Javanese people">Javanese</a>. A shared identity has developed, defined by a national language, ethnic diversity, religious pluralism within a majority Muslim population, and a history of colonialism and rebellion against it. Indonesia's national motto, <i>"Bhinneka Tunggal Ika"</i> ("Unity in Diversity" <i>literally,</i> "many, yet one"), articulates the diversity that shapes the country. Despite its large population and densely populated regions, Indonesia has vast areas of wilderness that support the world's second highest level of <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity" title="Biodiversity">biodiversity</a>. The country has abundant natural resources, yet poverty remains widespread.<sup id="cite_ref-economist1_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-economist1-7">[7]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Asia_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Asia-8">[8]</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Etymology"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Etymology</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#History"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">History</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Government_and_politics"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Government and politics</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#Foreign_relations_and_military"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Foreign relations and military</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#Administrative_divisions"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">Administrative divisions</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="#Geography"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">Geography</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-7"><a href="#Biota_and_environment"><span class="tocnumber">7</span> <span class="toctext">Biota and environment</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-8"><a href="#Economy"><span class="tocnumber">8</span> <span class="toctext">Economy</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-9"><a href="#Demographics"><span class="tocnumber">9</span> <span class="toctext">Demographics</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-10"><a href="#Culture"><span class="tocnumber">10</span> <span class="toctext">Culture</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-11"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">11</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-12"><a href="#Notes"><span class="tocnumber">12</span> <span class="toctext">Notes</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-13"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">13</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-14"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">14</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The name <i>Indonesia</i> derives from the Greek words <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indus (page does not exist)">Indós</a></i> and <i>nèsos</i>, which means "island".<sup id="cite_ref-EcoSeas1_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EcoSeas1-9">[9]</a></sup> The name dates to the 18th century, far predating the formation of independent Indonesia.<sup id="cite_ref-indoety_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-indoety-10">[10]</a></sup> In 1850, <a href="/w/index.php?title=George_Windsor_Earl&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="George Windsor Earl (page does not exist)">George Windsor Earl</a>, an English <a href="/wiki/Ethnology" title="Ethnology">ethnologist</a>, proposed the terms <i>Indunesians</i>&#160;— and, his preference, <i>Malayunesians</i>&#160;— for the inhabitants of the "Indian Archipelago or Malayan Archipelago".<sup id="cite_ref-JIAEA_1_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JIAEA_1-11">[11]</a></sup> In the same publication, a student of Earl's, <a href="/w/index.php?title=James_Richardson_Logan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="James Richardson Logan (page does not exist)">James Richardson Logan</a>, used <i>Indonesia</i> as a synonym for <i>Indian Archipelago</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-JIAEA_3_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JIAEA_3-12">[12]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> However, Dutch academics writing in East Indies publications were reluctant to use <i>Indonesia</i>. Instead, they used the terms <i>Malay Archipelago</i> (<i>Maleische Archipel</i>); the <i>Netherlands East Indies</i> (<i>Nederlandsch Oost Indië</i>), popularly <i>Indië</i>; <i>the East</i> (<i>de Oost</i>); and <i>Insulinde</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Kroef_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kroef-14">[14]</a></sup>
</p><p>After 1900, the name <i>Indonesia</i> became more common in academic circles outside the Netherlands, and Indonesian nationalist groups adopted it for political expression.<sup id="cite_ref-Kroef_14-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kroef-14">[14]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Adolf_Bastian" title="Adolf Bastian">Adolf Bastian</a>, of the University of Berlin, popularized the name through his book <i>Indonesien oder die Inseln des Malayischen Archipels, 1884–1894</i>. The first Indonesian scholar to use the name was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ki_Hajar_Dewantara&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ki Hajar Dewantara (page does not exist)">Suwardi Suryaningrat</a> (Ki Hajar Dewantara), when he established a press bureau in the Netherlands with the name <i>Indonesisch Pers-bureau</i> in 1913.<sup id="cite_ref-indoety_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-indoety-10">[10]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Borobudur_ship.JPG" title="File:Borobudur ship.JPG">File:Borobudur ship.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A <a href="/w/index.php?title=Borobudur_ship&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Borobudur ship (page does not exist)">Borobudur ship</a> carved on <a href="/wiki/Borobudur" title="Borobudur">Borobudur</a>, c. 800&#160;CE. Indonesian outrigger boats may have made trade voyages to the east coast of Africa as early as the 1st century CE.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Fossils and the remains of tools show that the Indonesian archipelago was inhabited by <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Homo_erectus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Homo erectus (page does not exist)">Homo erectus</a></i>, popularly known as "<a href="/wiki/Java_Man" title="Java Man">Java Man</a>", between 1.5 million years ago and as recently as 35,000 years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Homo_sapiens" title="Homo sapiens">Homo sapiens</a></i> reached the region by around 45,000 years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> In 2011 evidence was uncovered in neighbouring <a href="/w/index.php?title=East_Timor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="East Timor (page does not exist)">East Timor</a> showing that 42,000 years ago these early settlers had high-level maritime skills, and by implication the technology needed to make ocean crossings to reach Australia and other islands, as the evidence shows that they were catching and consuming large numbers of big deep sea fish such as tuna.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Austronesian_peoples&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Austronesian peoples (page does not exist)">Austronesian peoples</a>, who form the majority of the modern population, migrated to South East Asia from Taiwan. They arrived in Indonesia around 2000&#160;BCE, and as they spread through the archipelago, pushed the indigenous <a href="/wiki/Melanesia" title="Melanesia">Melanesian peoples</a> to the far eastern regions.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup> Ideal agricultural conditions, and the mastering of <a href="/wiki/Paddy_field" title="Paddy field">wet-field rice cultivation</a> as early as the 8th century BCE,<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> allowed villages, towns, and small kingdoms to flourish by the 1st century CE. Indonesia's strategic sea-lane position fostered inter-island and international trade, including links with Indian kingdoms and China, which were established several centuries BCE.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> Trade has since fundamentally shaped Indonesian history.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Myristica_fragrans_-_K%C3%B6hler%E2%80%93s_Medizinal-Pflanzen-097.jpg" title="File:Myristica fragrans - Köhler–s Medizinal-Pflanzen-097.jpg">File:Myristica fragrans - Köhler–s Medizinal-Pflanzen-097.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Nutmeg" title="Nutmeg">nutmeg</a> plant is native to Indonesia's <a href="/wiki/Banda_Islands" title="Banda Islands">Banda Islands</a>. Once one of the world's most valuable commodities, it drew the first European colonial powers to Indonesia.</div></div></div> Hinduism and Mahayana Buddhism arrived in Indonesia in the 4th and 5th century, as trade with India intensified under the south Indian <a href="/wiki/Pallava_dynasty" title="Pallava dynasty">Pallava dynasty</a><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup>
<p>From the 7th century, the powerful <a href="/wiki/Srivijaya" title="Srivijaya">Srivijaya</a> naval kingdom flourished as a result of trade and the influences of <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Buddhism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Buddhism (page does not exist)">Buddhism</a> that were imported with it.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup> Between the 8th and 10th centuries, the agricultural Buddhist <a href="/wiki/Sailendra" title="Sailendra">Sailendra</a> and Hindu <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mataram_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mataram Kingdom (page does not exist)">Mataram</a> dynasties thrived and declined in inland Java, leaving grand religious monuments such as Sailendra's <a href="/wiki/Borobudur" title="Borobudur">Borobudur</a> and Mataram's <a href="/wiki/Prambanan" title="Prambanan">Prambanan</a>. The Hindu <a href="/wiki/Majapahit" title="Majapahit">Majapahit</a> kingdom was founded in eastern Java in the late 13th century, and under <a href="/wiki/Gajah_Mada" title="Gajah Mada">Gajah Mada</a>, its influence stretched over much of Indonesia.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup>
</p><p>Although Muslim traders first traveled through Southeast Asia early in the Islamic era, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_spread_of_Islam_in_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The spread of Islam in Indonesia (page does not exist)">earliest evidence of Islamized populations</a> in Indonesia dates to the 13th century in northern <a href="/wiki/Sumatra" title="Sumatra">Sumatra</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup> Other Indonesian areas gradually adopted Islam, and it was the dominant religion in Java and Sumatra by the end of the 16th century. For the most part, Islam overlaid and mixed with existing cultural and religious influences, which shaped the predominant form of Islam in Indonesia, particularly in Java.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Portuguese_in_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Portuguese in Indonesia (page does not exist)">The first regular contact between Europeans and the peoples of Indonesia</a> began in 1512, when Portuguese traders, led by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Francisco_Serr%C3%A3o&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Francisco Serrão (page does not exist)">Francisco Serrão</a>, sought to monopolize the sources of nutmeg, <a href="/wiki/Clove" title="Clove">cloves</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cubeb&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cubeb (page does not exist)">cubeb pepper</a> in Maluku.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> Dutch and British traders followed. In 1602 the Dutch established the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dutch_East_India_Company_in_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dutch East India Company in Indonesia (page does not exist)">Dutch East India Company</a> (VOC) and became the dominant European power. Following bankruptcy, the VOC was formally dissolved in 1800, and the government of the Netherlands established the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dutch_East_Indies&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dutch East Indies (page does not exist)">Dutch East Indies</a> as a nationalized colony.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup>
</p><p>For most of <a href="/wiki/History_of_Indonesia#Colonial_era" title="History of Indonesia">the colonial period</a>, Dutch control over the archipelago was tenuous outside of coastal strongholds; only in the early 20th century did Dutch dominance extend to what was to become Indonesia's present boundaries.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_occupation_of_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese occupation of Indonesia (page does not exist)">Japanese occupation</a> during the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Second_World_War&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Second World War (page does not exist)">Second World War</a> ended Dutch rule<sup id="cite_ref-Ricklefs_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ricklefs-35">[35]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> and encouraged the previously suppressed Indonesian independence movement.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup> A later UN report stated that four million people died in Indonesia as a result of the Japanese occupation.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> Two days after the surrender of Japan in August 1945, <a href="/wiki/Sukarno" title="Sukarno">Sukarno</a>, an influential nationalist leader, declared independence and was appointed <a href="/w/index.php?title=President_of_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="President of Indonesia (page does not exist)">President</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Charles1945_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Charles1945-40">[40]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> The Netherlands tried to reestablish their rule, and the resulting conflict ended in December 1949, when in the face of international pressure, the Dutch formally recognized Indonesian independence<sup id="cite_ref-Charles1945_40-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Charles1945-40">[40]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> with the exception of <a href="/wiki/Netherlands_New_Guinea" title="Netherlands New Guinea">the Dutch territory of West New Guinea</a>, which was incorporated into Indonesia following the 1962 <a href="/wiki/New_York_Agreement" title="New York Agreement">New York Agreement</a>, and the UN-mandated <a href="/wiki/Act_of_Free_Choice" title="Act of Free Choice">Act of Free Choice</a> of 1969 <sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> which was questionable and has resulted in a longtime independence movement .<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Presiden_Sukarno.jpg" title="File:Presiden Sukarno.jpg">File:Presiden Sukarno.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Sukarno" title="Sukarno">Sukarno</a>, Indonesia's founding President.</div></div></div>
<p>Sukarno moved Indonesia from democracy towards authoritarianism, and maintained his power base by balancing the opposing forces of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Military_of_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Military of Indonesia (page does not exist)">military</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Indonesia" title="Communist Party of Indonesia">Communist Party of Indonesia</a> (PKI).<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Transition_to_the_New_Order&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Transition to the New Order (page does not exist)">An attempted coup</a> on 30 September 1965 was countered by the army, who led <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indonesian_killings_of_1965%E2%80%931966&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indonesian killings of 1965–1966 (page does not exist)">a violent anti-communist purge</a>, during which the PKI was blamed for the coup and effectively destroyed.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> Around 500,000 people are estimated to have been killed.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup> The head of the military, <a href="/wiki/Suharto" title="Suharto">General Suharto</a>, outmaneuvered the politically weakened Sukarno and was formally appointed president in March 1968. His <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_Order_(Indonesia)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New Order (Indonesia) (page does not exist)">New Order administration</a><sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup> was supported by the US government,<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup> and encouraged <a href="/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment" title="Foreign direct investment">foreign direct investment</a> in Indonesia, which was a major factor in the subsequent three decades of substantial economic growth. However, the authoritarian "New Order" was widely accused of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Corruption_in_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Corruption in Indonesia (page does not exist)">corruption</a> and suppression of political opposition.<sup id="cite_ref-Ricklefs_35-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ricklefs-35">[35]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup>
</p><p>Indonesia was the country hardest hit by the <a href="/wiki/1997_Asian_financial_crisis" title="1997 Asian financial crisis">late 1990s Asian financial crisis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup> This led to popular protest against the New Order which led to <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Suharto" title="Fall of Suharto">Suharto's resignation</a> in May 1998.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup> In 1999, East Timor voted to secede from Indonesia, after <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indonesian_occupation_of_East_Timor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indonesian occupation of East Timor (page does not exist)">a twenty-five-year military occupation</a> that was marked by international condemnation of repression of the East Timorese.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup> Since Suharto's resignation, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Post-Suharto_era&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Post-Suharto era (page does not exist)">a strengthening of democratic processes</a> has included a regional autonomy program, and the first <a href="/wiki/Indonesian_presidential_election,_2004" title="Indonesian presidential election, 2004">direct presidential election in 2004</a>. Political and economic instability, social unrest, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Corruption_in_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Corruption in Indonesia (page does not exist)">corruption</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Terrorism_in_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Terrorism in Indonesia (page does not exist)">terrorism</a> slowed progress; however, in the last five years the economy has performed strongly. Although relations among different religious and ethnic groups are largely harmonious, sectarian discontent and violence have persisted.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup> A political settlement to an armed separatist conflict in <a href="/wiki/Aceh" title="Aceh">Aceh</a> was achieved in 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Indonesia_DPR_session.jpg" title="File:Indonesia DPR session.jpg">File:Indonesia DPR session.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A session of the People's Representative Council in Jakarta</div></div></div>
<p>Indonesia is a republic with a presidential system. As a unitary state, power is concentrated in the central government. Following the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indonesian_Revolution_of_1998&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indonesian Revolution of 1998 (page does not exist)">resignation of President Suharto</a> in 1998, Indonesian political and governmental structures have undergone major reforms. Four amendments to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Constitution_of_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Constitution of Indonesia (page does not exist)">1945 Constitution of Indonesia</a><sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup> have revamped the <a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">executive</a>, <a href="/wiki/Judiciary" title="Judiciary">judicial</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Legislature" title="Legislature">legislative</a> branches.<sup id="cite_ref-Harijanti2006_64-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Harijanti2006-64">[64]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=President_of_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="President of Indonesia (page does not exist)">president of Indonesia</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a> and <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a>, <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">commander-in-chief</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Indonesian_National_Armed_Forces" title="Indonesian National Armed Forces">Indonesian National Armed Forces</a>, and the director of domestic governance, policy-making, and foreign affairs. The president appoints a council of ministers, who are not required to be elected members of the legislature. The 2004 presidential election was the first in which the people directly elected the president and vice president.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup> The president may serve a maximum of two consecutive five-year terms.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup>
</p><p>The highest representative body at national level is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=People%27s_Consultative_Assembly&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="People's Consultative Assembly (page does not exist)">People's Consultative Assembly</a> (MPR). Its main functions are supporting and amending the constitution, inaugurating the president, and formalizing broad outlines of state policy. It has the power to impeach the president.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup> The MPR comprises two houses; the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Representative_Council" title="People's Representative Council">People's Representative Council</a> (DPR), with 560 members, and the <a href="/wiki/Regional_Representative_Council" title="Regional Representative Council">Regional Representative Council</a> (DPD), with 132 members.<sup id="cite_ref-USSTATE_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USSTATE-68">[68]</a></sup> The DPR passes legislation and monitors the executive branch; party-aligned members are elected for five-year terms by <a href="/wiki/Proportional_representation" title="Proportional representation">proportional representation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Harijanti2006_64-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Harijanti2006-64">[64]</a></sup> Reforms since 1998 have markedly increased the DPR's role in national governance.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> The DPD is a new chamber for matters of regional management.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup>
</p><p>Most civil disputes appear before a State Court (Pengadilan Negeri); appeals are heard before the High Court (Pengadilan Tinggi). The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Supreme_Court_of_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Supreme Court of Indonesia (page does not exist)">Supreme Court (Mahkamah Agung)</a> is the country's highest court, and hears final cessation appeals and conducts case reviews. Other courts include the Commercial Court, which handles bankruptcy and insolvency; a State Administrative Court (Pengadilan Tata Negara) to hear administrative law cases against the government; a Constitutional Court (Mahkamah Konstitusi) to hear disputes concerning legality of law, general elections, dissolution of political parties, and the scope of authority of state institutions; and a Religious Court (Pengadilan Agama) to deal with codified Sharia Law cases.<sup id="cite_ref-USCONGRESS_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USCONGRESS-71">[71]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations_and_military">Foreign relations and military</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Obama_and_Susilo_Bambang_Yudhoyono_in_arrival_ceremony_cropped.jpg" title="File:Obama and Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono in arrival ceremony cropped.jpg">File:Obama and Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono in arrival ceremony cropped.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=President_of_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="President of Indonesia (page does not exist)">President of Indonesia</a> <a href="/wiki/Susilo_Bambang_Yudhoyono" title="Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono">Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono</a> with <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a>, the <a href="/wiki/President_of_United_States" title="President of United States" class="mw-redirect">President of United States</a>, in ceremony at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Istana_Merdeka&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Istana Merdeka (page does not exist)">Istana Merdeka</a> in Jakarta, 9 November 2010. Obama has become popular in Indonesia due to the years he spent in Jakarta as a child.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>In contrast to Sukarno's anti-imperialistic <a href="/wiki/Antipathy" title="Antipathy">antipathy</a> to western powers and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indonesia-Malaysia_confrontation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indonesia-Malaysia confrontation (page does not exist)">tensions with Malaysia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Indonesia" title="Foreign relations of Indonesia">Indonesia's foreign relations</a> since the Suharto "New Order" have been based on economic and political cooperation with Western nations.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup> Indonesia maintains close relationships with its neighbors in Asia, and is a founding member of <a href="/wiki/Association_of_Southeast_Asian_Nations" title="Association of Southeast Asian Nations">ASEAN</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=East_Asia_Summit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="East Asia Summit (page does not exist)">East Asia Summit</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-USSTATE_68-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USSTATE-68">[68]</a></sup> The nation restored relations with the People's Republic of China in 1990 following a freeze in place since anti-communist purges early in the Suharto era.<sup id="cite_ref-USCONGRESS_71-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USCONGRESS-71">[71]</a></sup> Indonesia has been a member of the United Nations since 1950,<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup> and was a founder of the <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a> (NAM) and the Organisation of the Islamic Conference (OIC, now the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation" title="Organisation of Islamic Cooperation">Organisation of Islamic Cooperation</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-USSTATE_68-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USSTATE-68">[68]</a></sup> Indonesia is signatory to the <a href="/wiki/ASEAN_Free_Trade_Area" title="ASEAN Free Trade Area">ASEAN Free Trade Area</a> agreement, the <a href="/wiki/Cairns_Group" title="Cairns Group">Cairns Group</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">WTO</a>, and has historically been a member of <a href="/wiki/OPEC" title="OPEC">OPEC</a>, although it withdrew in 2008 as it was no longer a net exporter of oil. Indonesia has received humanitarian and development aid since 1966, in particular from the United States, western Europe, Australia, and Japan.<sup id="cite_ref-USSTATE_68-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USSTATE-68">[68]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Indonesian Government has worked with other countries to apprehend and prosecute perpetrators of major bombings linked to militant <a href="/wiki/Islamism" title="Islamism">Islamism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Al-Qaeda" title="Al-Qaeda">Al-Qaeda</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup> The deadliest bombing killed 202 people (including 164 international tourists) in the <a href="/wiki/Bali" title="Bali">Bali</a> resort town of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kuta (page does not exist)">Kuta</a> in 2002.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup> The attacks, and subsequent travel warnings issued by other countries, severely damaged Indonesia's <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Indonesia" title="Tourism in Indonesia">tourism industry</a> and foreign investment prospects.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup>
</p><p>Indonesia's armed forces (TNI) include the <a href="/wiki/Indonesian_Army" title="Indonesian Army">Army</a> (TNI–AD), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indonesian_Navy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indonesian Navy (page does not exist)">Navy</a> (TNI–AL, which includes marines), and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indonesian_Air_Force&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indonesian Air Force (page does not exist)">Air Force</a> (TNI–AU).<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup> The army has about 400,000 active-duty personnel. Defense spending in the national budget was 4% of GDP in 2006, and is controversially supplemented by revenue from military commercial interests and foundations.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup> One of the reforms following the 1998 resignation of Suharto was the removal of formal TNI representation in parliament; nevertheless, its political influence remains extensive.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup>
</p><p>Separatist movements in the provinces of Aceh and Papua have led to armed conflict, and subsequent allegations of human rights abuses and brutality from all sides.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup> Following a sporadic thirty-year guerrilla war between the <a href="/wiki/Free_Aceh_Movement" title="Free Aceh Movement">Free Aceh Movement (GAM)</a> and the Indonesian military, a ceasefire agreement was reached in 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup> In Papua, there has been a significant, albeit imperfect, implementation of regional autonomy laws, and a reported decline in the levels of violence and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Human_rights_in_western_New_Guinea&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Human rights in western New Guinea (page does not exist)">human rights abuses</a>, since the presidency of Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Administratively, Indonesia consists of 34 provinces, five of which have special status. Each province has its own legislature and governor. The provinces are subdivided into regencies (<i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Regencies_of_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Regencies of Indonesia (page does not exist)">kabupaten</a></i>) and cities (<i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cities_of_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cities of Indonesia (page does not exist)">kota</a></i>), which are further subdivided into <a href="/w/index.php?title=Subdistricts_of_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Subdistricts of Indonesia (page does not exist)">districts</a> (<i>kecamatan</i> or <i>distrik</i> in Papua and West Papua), and again into <a href="/w/index.php?title=Village_(Indonesia)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Village (Indonesia) (page does not exist)">administrative villages</a> (either <i>desa</i>, <i>kelurahan</i>, <i>kampung</i>, <i>nagari</i> in West Sumatra, or <i>gampong</i> in Aceh). Village is the lowest level of government administration in Indonesia. Furthermore, a village is divided into several community groups (Rukun-Warga (RW)) which are further divided into neighbourhood groups (Rukun-Tetangga (RT)). In Java the <i>desa</i> (village) is divided further into smaller units called <i>dusun</i> or <i>dukuh</i> (hamlets), these units are the same as Rukun-Warga. Following the implementation of regional autonomy measures in 2001, the regencies and cities have become the key administrative units, responsible for providing most government services. The village administration level is the most influential on a citizen's daily life and handles matters of a village or neighborhood through an elected <i>lurah</i> or <i>kepala desa</i> (village chief).
</p><p>The provinces of <a href="/wiki/Aceh" title="Aceh">Aceh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jakarta" title="Jakarta">Jakarta</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yogyakarta_(special_region)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yogyakarta (special region) (page does not exist)">Yogyakarta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Papua_(province)" title="Papua (province)">Papua</a>, and <a href="/wiki/West_Papua_(province)" title="West Papua (province)">West Papua</a> have greater legislative privileges and a higher degree of autonomy from the central government than the other provinces. The Acehnese government, for example, has the right to create certain elements of an independent legal system; in 2003, it instituted a form of <i><a href="/wiki/Sharia_Law" title="Sharia Law" class="mw-redirect">Sharia Law</a></i> (Islamic law).<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup> Yogyakarta was granted the status of Special Region in recognition of its pivotal role in supporting Indonesian Republicans during the Indonesian Revolution and its willingness to join Indonesia as a republic.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup> Papua, formerly known as Irian Jaya, was granted special autonomy status in 2001 and was split into <a href="/w/index.php?title=Papua_(Indonesian_province)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Papua (Indonesian province) (page does not exist)">Papua</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=West_Papua_(Indonesian_province)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="West Papua (Indonesian province) (page does not exist)">West Papua</a> in February 2003.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup> Jakarta is the country's special capital region.
</p>
<center>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Indonesia_provinces&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Indonesia provinces (page does not exist)">Template:Indonesia provinces</a>
</p>
</center>
<dl>
<dt>Indonesian provinces and their capitals, listed by region
</dt>
</dl>
<p>Indonesian name is in parentheses if different from English.
<br />* indicates provinces with Special Status
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Col-begin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Col-begin (page does not exist)">Template:Col-begin</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Col-break&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Col-break (page does not exist)">Template:Col-break</a>
<b><a href="/wiki/Sumatra" title="Sumatra">Sumatra</a></b>
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Aceh" title="Aceh">Aceh</a><sup>*</sup>&#160;– <a href="/wiki/Banda_Aceh" title="Banda Aceh">Banda Aceh</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/North_Sumatra" title="North Sumatra">North Sumatra</a> (<i>Sumatera Utara</i>)&#160;– <a href="/wiki/Medan" title="Medan">Medan</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/West_Sumatra" title="West Sumatra">West Sumatra</a> (<i>Sumatera Barat</i>)&#160;– <a href="/wiki/Padang" title="Padang">Padang</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Riau" title="Riau">Riau</a>&#160;– <a href="/wiki/Pekanbaru" title="Pekanbaru">Pekanbaru</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Riau_Islands&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Riau Islands (page does not exist)">Riau Islands</a> (<i>Kepulauan Riau</i>)&#160;– <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tanjung_Pinang&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tanjung Pinang (page does not exist)">Tanjung Pinang</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Jambi" title="Jambi">Jambi</a>&#160;– <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jambi_(city)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jambi (city) (page does not exist)">Jambi (city)</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/South_Sumatra" title="South Sumatra">South Sumatra</a> (<i>Sumatera Selatan</i>)&#160;– <a href="/wiki/Palembang" title="Palembang">Palembang</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bangka-Belitung&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bangka-Belitung (page does not exist)">Bangka-Belitung</a> (<i>Kepulauan Bangka-Belitung</i>)&#160;– <a href="/wiki/Pangkal_Pinang" title="Pangkal Pinang">Pangkal Pinang</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Bengkulu" title="Bengkulu">Bengkulu</a>&#160;– <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bengkulu_(city)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bengkulu (city) (page does not exist)">Bengkulu (city)</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Lampung" title="Lampung">Lampung</a>&#160;– <a href="/wiki/Bandar_Lampung" title="Bandar Lampung">Bandar Lampung</a>
</li>
</ul>
<p><b><a href="/wiki/Java" title="Java">Java</a></b>
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Jakarta" title="Jakarta">Special Capital Region of Jakarta</a><sup>*</sup> (<i>Daerah Khusus Ibu Kota Jakarta</i>) &#160;– Jakarta
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Banten" title="Banten">Banten</a>&#160;– <a href="/w/index.php?title=Serang&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Serang (page does not exist)">Serang</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/West_Java" title="West Java">West Java</a> (<i>Jawa Barat</i>)&#160;– <a href="/wiki/Bandung" title="Bandung">Bandung</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Central_Java" title="Central Java">Central Java</a> (<i>Jawa Tengah</i>)&#160;– <a href="/wiki/Semarang" title="Semarang">Semarang</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yogyakarta_Special_Region&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yogyakarta Special Region (page does not exist)">Yogyakarta Special Region</a><sup>*</sup> (<i>Daerah Istimewa Yogyakarta</i>)&#160;– <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yogyakarta_(city)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yogyakarta (city) (page does not exist)">Yogyakarta (city)</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/East_Java" title="East Java">East Java</a> (<i>Jawa Timur</i>)&#160;– <a href="/wiki/Surabaya" title="Surabaya">Surabaya</a>
</li>
</ul>
<p><b><a href="/wiki/Lesser_Sunda_Islands" title="Lesser Sunda Islands">Lesser Sunda Islands</a></b>
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Bali" title="Bali">Bali</a>&#160;– <a href="/wiki/Denpasar" title="Denpasar">Denpasar</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/West_Nusa_Tenggara" title="West Nusa Tenggara">West Nusa Tenggara</a> (<i>Nusa Tenggara Barat</i>)&#160;– <a href="/wiki/Mataram_(city)" title="Mataram (city)">Mataram</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/East_Nusa_Tenggara" title="East Nusa Tenggara">East Nusa Tenggara</a> (<i>Nusa Tenggara Timur</i>)&#160;– <a href="/wiki/Kupang" title="Kupang">Kupang</a>
</li>
</ul>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Col-break&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Col-break (page does not exist)">Template:Col-break</a>
</p><p><b><a href="/wiki/Kalimantan" title="Kalimantan">Kalimantan</a></b>
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/wiki/West_Kalimantan" title="West Kalimantan">West Kalimantan</a> (<i>Kalimantan Barat</i>)&#160;– <a href="/wiki/Pontianak,_Indonesia" title="Pontianak, Indonesia">Pontianak</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Central_Kalimantan" title="Central Kalimantan">Central Kalimantan</a> (<i>Kalimantan Tengah</i>)&#160;– <a href="/w/index.php?title=Palangkaraya&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Palangkaraya (page does not exist)">Palangkaraya</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/South_Kalimantan" title="South Kalimantan">South Kalimantan</a> (<i>Kalimantan Selatan</i>)&#160;– <a href="/wiki/Banjarmasin" title="Banjarmasin">Banjarmasin</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/East_Kalimantan" title="East Kalimantan">East Kalimantan</a> (<i>Kalimantan Timur</i>)&#160;– <a href="/wiki/Samarinda" title="Samarinda">Samarinda</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=North_Kalimantan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="North Kalimantan (page does not exist)">North Kalimantan</a> (<i>Kalimantan Utara</i>)&#160;– <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tanjung_Selor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tanjung Selor (page does not exist)">Tanjung Selor</a>
</li>
</ul>
<p><b><a href="/wiki/Sulawesi" title="Sulawesi">Sulawesi</a></b>
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/wiki/North_Sulawesi" title="North Sulawesi">North Sulawesi</a> (<i>Sulawesi Utara</i>)&#160;– <a href="/wiki/Manado" title="Manado">Manado</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Gorontalo_(province)" title="Gorontalo (province)">Gorontalo</a>&#160;– <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gorontalo_(city)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gorontalo (city) (page does not exist)">Gorontalo (city)</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Central_Sulawesi" title="Central Sulawesi">Central Sulawesi</a> (<i>Sulawesi Tengah</i>)&#160;– <a href="/wiki/Palu" title="Palu">Palu</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/West_Sulawesi" title="West Sulawesi">West Sulawesi</a> (<i>Sulawesi Barat</i>)&#160;– <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mamuju_(city)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mamuju (city) (page does not exist)">Mamuju</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/South_Sulawesi" title="South Sulawesi">South Sulawesi</a> (<i>Sulawesi Selatan</i>)&#160;– <a href="/wiki/Makassar" title="Makassar">Makassar</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=South_East_Sulawesi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="South East Sulawesi (page does not exist)">South East Sulawesi</a> (<i>Sulawesi Tenggara</i>)&#160;– <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kendari&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kendari (page does not exist)">Kendari</a>
</li>
</ul>
<p><b><a href="/wiki/Maluku_Islands" title="Maluku Islands">Maluku Islands</a></b>
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maluku_(Indonesian_province)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maluku (Indonesian province) (page does not exist)">Maluku</a>&#160;– <a href="/wiki/Ambon,_Maluku" title="Ambon, Maluku">Ambon</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/North_Maluku" title="North Maluku">North Maluku</a> (<i>Maluku Utara</i>)&#160;– <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sofifi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sofifi (page does not exist)">Sofifi</a>
</li>
</ul>
<p><b><a href="/w/index.php?title=Western_New_Guinea&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Western New Guinea (page does not exist)">Western New Guinea</a></b>
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/wiki/West_Papua_(province)" title="West Papua (province)">West Papua</a><sup>*</sup> (<i>Papua Barat</i>)&#160;– <a href="/wiki/Manokwari" title="Manokwari">Manokwari</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Papua_(province)" title="Papua (province)">Papua</a><sup>*</sup>&#160;– <a href="/wiki/Jayapura" title="Jayapura">Jayapura</a>
</li>
</ul>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Col-end&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Col-end (page does not exist)">Template:Col-end</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Indonesia_2002_CIA_map.png" title="File:Indonesia 2002 CIA map.png">File:Indonesia 2002 CIA map.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Map of Indonesia</div></div></div>
<p>Indonesia lies between latitudes <a href="/w/index.php?title=11th_parallel_south&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="11th parallel south (page does not exist)">11°S</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=6th_parallel_north&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="6th parallel north (page does not exist)">6°N</a>, and longitudes <a href="/w/index.php?title=95th_meridian_east&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="95th meridian east (page does not exist)">95°E</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=141st_meridian_east&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="141st meridian east (page does not exist)">141°E</a>. It consists of 17,508 islands, about 6,000 of which are inhabited.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup> These are scattered over both sides of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Equator&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Equator (page does not exist)">equator</a>. The largest are Java, Sumatra, <a href="/wiki/Borneo" title="Borneo">Borneo</a> (shared with Brunei and Malaysia), New Guinea (shared with Papua New Guinea), and Sulawesi. Indonesia shares land borders with Malaysia on Borneo, Papua New Guinea on the island of New Guinea, and East Timor on the island of <a href="/wiki/Timor" title="Timor">Timor</a>. Indonesia shares maritime borders across narrow straits with Singapore, Malaysia, the Philippines, and Palau to the north, and with Australia to the south. The capital, Jakarta, is on Java and is the nation's largest city, followed by Surabaya, Bandung, Medan, and Semarang.<sup id="cite_ref-Witton2003_90-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Witton2003-90">[90]</a></sup>
</p><p>At 1,919,440&#160;square kilometers (741,050&#160;sq&#160;mi), Indonesia is the world's <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_and_outlying_territories_by_land_area&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries and outlying territories by land area (page does not exist)">15th-largest country</a> in terms of land area and world's <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_and_outlying_territories_by_land_area&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries and outlying territories by land area (page does not exist)">7th-largest country</a> in terms of combined sea and land area.<sup id="cite_ref-ciarank_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ciarank-91">[91]</a></sup> Its average population density is 134&#160;people per square kilometer (347&#160;per sq&#160;mi), 79th in the world,<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup> although Java, the world's most populous island,<sup id="cite_ref-JOSHUA_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JOSHUA-93">[93]</a></sup> has a population density of 940&#160;people per square kilometer (2,435&#160;per sq&#160;mi). At <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Puncak_Jaya&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Puncak Jaya (page does not exist)">Puncak Jaya</a> in Papua is Indonesia's highest peak, and <a href="/wiki/Lake_Toba" title="Lake Toba">Lake Toba</a> in Sumatra its largest lake, with an area of 1,145&#160;square kilometers (442&#160;sq&#160;mi). The country's largest rivers are in Kalimantan, and include the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mahakam&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mahakam (page does not exist)">Mahakam</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Barito&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Barito (page does not exist)">Barito</a>; such rivers are communication and transport links between the island's river settlements.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mahameru-volcano.jpeg" title="File:Mahameru-volcano.jpeg">File:Mahameru-volcano.jpeg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Mount_Semeru" title="Mount Semeru" class="mw-redirect">Mount Semeru</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mount_Bromo" title="Mount Bromo">Mount Bromo</a> in East Java. Indonesia's seismic and volcanic activity is among the world's highest.</div></div></div>
<p>Indonesia's location on the edges of the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_plate" title="Pacific plate" class="mw-redirect">Pacific</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_plate" title="Eurasian plate" class="mw-redirect">Eurasian</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Australian_plate" title="Australian plate" class="mw-redirect">Australian</a> <a href="/wiki/Tectonic_plate" title="Tectonic plate" class="mw-redirect">tectonic plates</a> makes it the site of numerous <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_volcanoes_in_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of volcanoes in Indonesia (page does not exist)">volcanoes</a> and frequent earthquakes. Indonesia has at least 150 active volcanoes,<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup> including <a href="/wiki/Krakatoa" title="Krakatoa">Krakatoa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mount_Tambora" title="Mount Tambora">Tambora</a>, both famous for their devastating eruptions in the 19th century. The eruption of the Toba <a href="/wiki/Supervolcano" title="Supervolcano">supervolcano</a>, approximately 70,000 years ago, was one of the largest eruptions ever, and a <a href="/wiki/Toba_catastrophe_theory" title="Toba catastrophe theory">global catastrophe</a>. Recent disasters due to seismic activity include the <a href="/wiki/2004_tsunami" title="2004 tsunami" class="mw-redirect">2004 tsunami</a> that killed an estimated 167,736 in northern Sumatra,<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=May_2006_Java_earthquake&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="May 2006 Java earthquake (page does not exist)">Yogyakarta earthquake</a> in 2006. However, <a href="/wiki/Volcanic_ash" title="Volcanic ash">volcanic ash</a> is a major contributor to the high agricultural fertility that has historically sustained the high population densities of Java and Bali.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup>
</p><p>{{#invoke:anchor|main}}
Lying along the equator, Indonesia has a <a href="/wiki/Tropical_climate" title="Tropical climate">tropical climate</a>, with two distinct <a href="/wiki/Monsoon" title="Monsoon">monsoonal</a> <a href="/wiki/Wet_season" title="Wet season">wet</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dry_season" title="Dry season">dry</a> seasons. Average annual rainfall in the lowlands varies from 1,780–3,175&#160;millimeters (70–125&#160;in), and up to 6,100&#160;millimeters (240&#160;in) in mountainous regions. Mountainous areas &#8211; particularly in the west coast of Sumatra, West Java, Kalimantan, Sulawesi, and Papua &#8211; receive the highest rainfall. Humidity is generally high, averaging about 80%. Temperatures vary little throughout the year; the average daily temperature range of Jakarta is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Biota_and_environment">Biota and environment</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Man_of_the_woods.JPG" title="File:Man of the woods.JPG">File:Man of the woods.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Endangered_species&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Endangered species (page does not exist)">critically endangered</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sumatran_Orangutan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sumatran Orangutan (page does not exist)">Sumatran Orangutan</a>, a great ape <a href="/wiki/Endemism" title="Endemism">endemic</a> to Indonesia.</div></div></div>
<p>Indonesia's size, tropical climate, and archipelagic geography, support the world's second highest level of biodiversity (after Brazil),<sup id="cite_ref-LESTER_99-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LESTER-99">[99]</a></sup> and its flora and fauna is a mixture of Asian and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Australasia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Australasia (page does not exist)">Australasian</a> species.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup> The islands of the <a href="/wiki/Sunda_Shelf" title="Sunda Shelf">Sunda Shelf</a> (Sumatra, Java, Borneo, and Bali) were once linked to the Asian mainland, and have a wealth of Asian fauna. Large species such as the <a href="/wiki/Sumatran_tiger" title="Sumatran tiger">tiger</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rhinoceros" title="Rhinoceros">rhinoceros</a>, <a href="/wiki/Orangutan" title="Orangutan">orangutan</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Asian_Elephant&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Asian Elephant (page does not exist)">elephant</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Leopard" title="Leopard">leopard</a>, were once abundant as far east as Bali, but numbers and distribution have dwindled drastically. Forests cover approximately 60% of the country.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup> In Sumatra and Kalimantan, these are predominantly of Asian species. However, the forests of the smaller, and more densely populated Java, have largely been removed for human habitation and agriculture. Sulawesi, Nusa Tenggara, and Maluku &#8211; having been long separated from the continental landmasses—have developed their own unique flora and fauna.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup> Papua was part of the Australian landmass, and is home to a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fauna_of_New_Guinea&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fauna of New Guinea (page does not exist)">unique fauna and flora</a> closely related to that of Australia, including over 600 bird species.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup>
</p><p>Indonesia is second only to Australia in terms of total endemic species, with 36% of its 1,531 species of bird and 39% of its 515 species of mammal being endemic.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup>
Indonesia's 80,000&#160;kilometers (50,000&#160;mi) of coastline are surrounded by tropical seas that contribute to the country's high level of biodiversity. Indonesia has a range of sea and coastal <a href="/wiki/Ecosystem" title="Ecosystem">ecosystems</a>, including <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_beaches_in_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of beaches in Indonesia (page does not exist)">beaches</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sand_dune" title="Sand dune" class="mw-redirect">sand dunes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Estuary" title="Estuary">estuaries</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mangroves" title="Mangroves" class="mw-redirect">mangroves</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coral_reef" title="Coral reef">coral reefs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sea_grass" title="Sea grass" class="mw-redirect">sea grass</a> beds, <a href="/wiki/Mudflat" title="Mudflat">coastal mudflats</a>, tidal flats, algal beds, and small island ecosystems.<sup id="cite_ref-EcoSeas1_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EcoSeas1-9">[9]</a></sup> Indonesia is one of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Coral_Triangle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Coral Triangle (page does not exist)">Coral Triangle</a> countries with the world's greatest diversity of coral reef fish with more than 1,650 species in eastern Indonesia only.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup> The British naturalist, <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Wallace" title="Alfred Wallace" class="mw-redirect">Alfred Wallace</a>, described a dividing line between the distribution and peace of Indonesia's Asian and Australasian species.<sup id="cite_ref-Severin_106-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Severin-106">[106]</a></sup> Known as the <a href="/wiki/Wallace_Line" title="Wallace Line">Wallace Line</a>, it runs roughly north-south along the edge of the Sunda Shelf, between Kalimantan and Sulawesi, and along the deep <a href="/wiki/Lombok_Strait" title="Lombok Strait">Lombok Strait</a>, between <a href="/wiki/Lombok" title="Lombok">Lombok</a> and Bali. West of the line the flora and fauna are more Asian; moving east from Lombok, they are increasingly Australian. In his 1869 book, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Malay_Archipelago&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Malay Archipelago (page does not exist)">The Malay Archipelago</a></i>, Wallace described numerous species unique to the area.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup> The region of islands between his line and New Guinea is now termed <a href="/wiki/Wallacea" title="Wallacea">Wallacea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Severin_106-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Severin-106">[106]</a></sup>
</p><p>Indonesia's high population and rapid industrialization present serious <a href="/w/index.php?title=Environmental_issues_in_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Environmental issues in Indonesia (page does not exist)">environmental issues</a>, which are often given a lower priority due to high poverty levels and weak, under-resourced governance.<sup id="cite_ref-forestprob_108-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-forestprob-108">[108]</a></sup> Issues include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Deforestation_in_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Deforestation in Indonesia (page does not exist)">large-scale deforestation</a> (much of it <a href="/wiki/Illegal_logging" title="Illegal logging">illegal</a>) and related wildfires causing <a href="/w/index.php?title=1997_Southeast_Asian_haze&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1997 Southeast Asian haze (page does not exist)">heavy smog</a> over parts of western Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore; over-exploitation of marine resources; and environmental problems associated with rapid urbanization and <a href="/wiki/Economic_development" title="Economic development">economic development</a>, including air pollution, <a href="/wiki/Traffic_congestion" title="Traffic congestion">traffic congestion</a>, garbage management, and reliable water and <a href="/wiki/Wastewater" title="Wastewater">waste water</a> services.<sup id="cite_ref-forestprob_108-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-forestprob-108">[108]</a></sup> Deforestation and the destruction of peatlands make Indonesia the world's third largest emitter of greenhouse gases.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Habitat_destruction" title="Habitat destruction">Habitat destruction</a> threatens the survival of indigenous and endemic species, including 140 species of <a href="/wiki/Mammals" title="Mammals" class="mw-redirect">mammals</a> identified by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_Conservation_Union&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World Conservation Union (page does not exist)">World Conservation Union</a> (IUCN) as <a href="/wiki/Threatened_species" title="Threatened species">threatened</a>, and 15 identified as critically endangered, including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bali_Starling&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bali Starling (page does not exist)">Bali Starling</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-IUCN_110-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IUCN-110">[110]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sumatran_Orangutan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sumatran Orangutan (page does not exist)">Sumatran Orangutan</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Javan_Rhinoceros&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Javan Rhinoceros (page does not exist)">Javan Rhinoceros</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-IUCN_110-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IUCN-110">[110]</a></sup> Much of Indonesia's deforestation is caused by forest clearing for the palm oil Industry, which has cleared 18 million hectares of forest for palm oil expansion. Palm oil expansion requires land reallocation as well as changes to the local and natural ecosystems. Palm oil expansion can generate wealth for local communities if done right. If down wrong it can degrade ecosystems and cause social conflicts.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:KerbauJawa.jpg" title="File:KerbauJawa.jpg">File:KerbauJawa.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Using <a href="/w/index.php?title=Domestic_buffalo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Domestic buffalo (page does not exist)">water buffalo</a> to plough rice fields in Java. Agriculture had been the country's largest employer for centuries.</div></div></div>
<p>Indonesia has a <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">mixed economy</a> in which both the private sector and government play significant roles.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup> The country is the largest economy in Southeast Asia and a member of the <a href="/wiki/G-20_major_economies" title="G-20 major economies">G-20 major economies</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup> Indonesia's estimated <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">gross domestic product (nominal)</a>, as of 2012 was US$928.274 billion with estimated nominal <a href="/w/index.php?title=Per_capita_GDP&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Per capita GDP (page does not exist)">per capita GDP</a> was US$3,797, and per capita GDP PPP was US$4,943 (<a href="/wiki/International_dollar" title="International dollar" class="mw-redirect">international dollars</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup> June 2011: At <a href="/wiki/World_Economic_Forum" title="World Economic Forum">World Economic Forum</a> on East Asia, Indonesian president said Indonesia will be in the top ten countries with the strongest economy within the next decade. The gross domestic product (GDP) is about $1 trillion<sup id="cite_ref-imf2_3-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-imf2-3">[3]</a></sup> and the debt ratio to the GDP is 26%.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Industry_sector" title="Industry sector" class="mw-redirect">industry sector</a> is the economy's largest and accounts for 46.4% of GDP (2012), this is followed by services (38.6%) and agriculture (14.4%). However, since 2012, the <a href="/wiki/Service_sector" title="Service sector" class="mw-redirect">service sector</a> has employed more people than other sectors, accounting for 48.9% of the total labor force, this has been followed by agriculture (38.6%) and industry (22.2%).<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup> Agriculture, however, had been the country's largest employer for centuries.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> data, Indonesia was the 27th biggest exporting country in the world in 2010, moving up three places from a year before.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup> Indonesia's main export markets (2009) are Japan (17.28%), <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a> (11.29%), <a href="/wiki/The_United_States" title="The United States" class="mw-redirect">the United States</a> (10.81%), and China (7.62%). The major suppliers of imports to Indonesia are Singapore (24.96%), China (12.52%), and Japan (8.92%). In 2005, Indonesia ran a trade surplus with export revenues of US$83.64 billion and import expenditure of US$62.02 billion. The country has extensive natural resources, including crude oil, natural gas, tin, copper, and gold. Indonesia's major imports include machinery and equipment, chemicals, fuels, and foodstuffs. And the country's major export commodities include oil and gas, electrical appliances, plywood, rubber, and textiles.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_121-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-121">[121]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Jakarta_Skyline_Part_2.jpg" title="File:Jakarta Skyline Part 2.jpg">File:Jakarta Skyline Part 2.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Jakarta" title="Jakarta">Jakarta</a>, the capital of Indonesia and the country's largest commercial center.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Indonesia" title="Tourism in Indonesia">tourism sector</a> contributes to around US$9 billion of foreign exchange in 2012, and ranked as the 4th largest among goods and services export sectors.<sup id="cite_ref-Kompas.com_122-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kompas.com-122">[122]</a></sup> Singapore, Malaysia, Australia, China and Japan are the top five source of visitors to Indonesia.
</p><p>In the 1960s the economy deteriorated drastically as a result of political instability, a young and inexperienced government, and economic nationalism, which resulted in severe poverty and hunger. By the time of Sukarno's downfall in the mid-1960s, the economy was in chaos with 1,000% annual inflation, shrinking export revenues, crumbling infrastructure, factories operating at minimal capacity, and negligible <a href="/wiki/Investment#In_economics_or_macroeconomics" title="Investment">investment</a>. Following President Sukarno's downfall in the mid-1960s, the New Order administration brought <a href="/wiki/Austerity" title="Austerity">a degree of discipline</a> to economic policy that quickly brought inflation down, stabilized the currency, rescheduled <a href="/wiki/Foreign_debt" title="Foreign debt" class="mw-redirect">foreign debt</a>, and attracted foreign aid and investment. (See <a href="/wiki/Berkeley_Mafia" title="Berkeley Mafia">Berkeley Mafia</a>). Indonesia was until recently Southeast Asia's only member of OPEC, and the 1970s oil price raises provided an export revenue windfall that contributed to sustained high economic growth rates, averaging over 7% from 1968 to 1981.<sup id="cite_ref-SCHWARZ_123-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SCHWARZ-123">[123]</a></sup> Following further reforms in the late 1980s,<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup> foreign investment flowed into Indonesia, particularly into the rapidly developing export-oriented <a href="/w/index.php?title=Secondary_sector_of_industry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Secondary sector of industry (page does not exist)">manufacturing sector</a>, and from 1989 to 1997, the Indonesian economy grew by an average of over 7%.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup>
</p><p>Indonesia was the country hardest hit by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Asian_financial_crisis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Asian financial crisis (page does not exist)">Asian financial crisis</a> of 1997–98. During the crisis there were sudden and large capital outflows leading the rupiah to go into free fall.
