Against the US dollar the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rupiah&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rupiah (page does not exist)">rupiah</a> dropped from about Rp 2,600 in late 1997 to a low point of around Rp 17,000 some months later and the economy shrank by a remarkable 13.7%.  These developments led to widespread economic distress across the economy and contributed to the political crisis of 1998 which saw Suharto resign as president.<sup id="cite_ref-CountryBrief_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CountryBrief-127">[127]</a></sup> The rupiah later stabilised in the Rp. 8,000–10,000 range<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup> and a slow but steady economic recovery ensued. However political instability, slow economic reform, and corruption slowed the recovery.<sup id="cite_ref-economist1_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-economist1-7">[7]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Asia_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Asia-8">[8]</a></sup> Transparency International, for example, has since ranked Indonesia below 100 in its <a href="/w/index.php?title=Corruption_Perceptions_Index&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Corruption Perceptions Index (page does not exist)">Corruption Perceptions Index</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup> Since 2007, however, with the improvement in banking sector and domestic consumption, national economic growth has accelerated to over 6% annually<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[131]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup> and this helped the country weather the 2008–2009 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Global_recession&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Global recession (page does not exist)">global recession</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> The Indonesian economy performed strongly during the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Global_Financial_Crisis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Global Financial Crisis (page does not exist)">Global Financial Crisis</a> and in 2012 its GDP grew by over 6%.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup> The country regained its investment grade rating in late 2011 after losing it in the 1997.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup> However, as of 2012, an estimated 11.7% of the population lived below the poverty line and the official open unemployment rate was 6.1%.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_121-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-121">[121]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ubud-Kids.jpg" title="File:Ubud-Kids.jpg">File:Ubud-Kids.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Balinese_people" title="Balinese people">Balinese</a> children. There are around 300 distinct native ethnicities in Indonesia.</div></div></div>
<p>According to the 2010 national census, the population of Indonesia is 237.6 million,<sup id="cite_ref-bps2010_137-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bps2010-137">[137]</a></sup> with high population growth at 1.9%.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[138]</a></sup> 58% of the population lives in <a href="/wiki/Java" title="Java">Java</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-bps2010_137-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bps2010-137">[137]</a></sup> the world's most populous island.<sup id="cite_ref-JOSHUA_93-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JOSHUA-93">[93]</a></sup> In 1961 the first post-colonial census gave a total population of 97 million.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup> Despite a fairly effective <a href="/wiki/Family_planning" title="Family planning">family planning</a> program that has been in place since the 1960s, population is expected to grow to around 265 million by 2020 and 306 million by 2050.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup>
</p><p>There are around <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ethnic_groups_in_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ethnic groups in Indonesia (page does not exist)">300 distinct native ethnic groups</a> in Indonesia, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Languages_of_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Languages of Indonesia (page does not exist)">742 different languages and dialects</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup> Most Indonesians are descended from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Austronesian&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Austronesian (page does not exist)">Austronesian</a>-speaking peoples whose languages can be traced to Proto-Austronesian (PAn), which possibly originated in Taiwan. Another major grouping are <a href="/wiki/Melanesians" title="Melanesians">Melanesians</a>, who inhabit eastern Indonesia.<sup id="cite_ref-Witton2003_90-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Witton2003-90">[90]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[143]</a></sup> The largest ethnic group is the <a href="/wiki/Javanese_people" title="Javanese people">Javanese</a>, who comprise 42% of the population, and are politically and culturally dominant.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Sundanese_people" title="Sundanese people">Sundanese</a>, ethnic <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malay_(ethnic_group)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Malay (ethnic group) (page does not exist)">Malays</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Madurese_people" title="Madurese people">Madurese</a> are the largest non-Javanese groups.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup> A sense of Indonesian nationhood exists alongside strong regional identities.<sup id="cite_ref-RICKLEFS_256_146-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RICKLEFS_256-146">[146]</a></sup> Society is largely harmonious, although social, religious and ethnic tensions have triggered horrendous violence.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chinese_Indonesian&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chinese Indonesian (page does not exist)">Chinese Indonesians</a> are an influential ethnic minority comprising 3–4% of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup> Much of the country's privately owned commerce and wealth is Chinese-Indonesian-controlled.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup> Chinese businesses in Indonesia are part of the larger <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bamboo_network&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bamboo network (page does not exist)">bamboo network</a>, a network of <a href="/wiki/Overseas_Chinese" title="Overseas Chinese">overseas Chinese</a> businesses operating in the markets of Southeast Asia that share common family and cultural ties.<sup id="cite_ref-Weidenbaum_153-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Weidenbaum-153">[153]</a></sup> This has contributed to considerable resentment, and even anti-Chinese violence.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Istiqlal_Mosque.jpg" title="File:Istiqlal Mosque.jpg">File:Istiqlal Mosque.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Istiqlal_Mosque,_Jakarta" title="Istiqlal Mosque, Jakarta">Istiqlal Mosque</a> in Central Jakarta. Indonesia is the world's most populous Muslim-majority nation.</div></div></div>
<p>The official national language is <a href="/wiki/Indonesian_language" title="Indonesian language">Indonesian</a>, a form of <a href="/wiki/Malay_language" title="Malay language">Malay</a>. It is based on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Prestige_dialect&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Prestige dialect (page does not exist)">prestige dialect</a> of Malay, that of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Johor-Riau_Sultanate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Johor-Riau Sultanate (page does not exist)">Johor-Riau Sultanate</a>, which for centuries had been the <a href="/wiki/Lingua_franca" title="Lingua franca">lingua franca</a> of the archipelago, standards of which are the official languages in Singapore, Malaysia and Brunei. Indonesian is universally taught in schools, consequently it is spoken by nearly every Indonesian. It is the language of business, politics, national media, education, and academia. It was promoted by Indonesian nationalists in the 1920s, and declared the <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">official language</a> under the name <i>Bahasa Indonesia</i> on the proclamation of independence in 1945. Most Indonesians speak at least one of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Languages_of_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Languages of Indonesia (page does not exist)">several hundred local languages and dialects</a>, often as their <a href="/wiki/First_language" title="First language">first language</a>. Of these, <a href="/wiki/Javanese_language" title="Javanese language">Javanese</a> is the most widely spoken as the language of the largest ethnic group.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_121-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-121">[121]</a></sup> On the other hand, Papua has over 270 indigenous <a href="/wiki/Papuan_languages" title="Papuan languages">Papuan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Austronesian_languages" title="Austronesian languages">Austronesian languages</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup> in a region of about 2.7 million people.
</p><p>While religious freedom is stipulated in the Indonesian constitution,<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup> the government officially recognizes only <a href="/w/index.php?title=Religion_in_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Religion in Indonesia (page does not exist)">six religions</a>: <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Indonesia" title="Islam in Indonesia">Islam</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Protestantism_in_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Protestantism in Indonesia (page does not exist)">Protestantism</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Roman_Catholicism_in_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Roman Catholicism in Indonesia (page does not exist)">Roman Catholicism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Indonesia" title="Hinduism in Indonesia">Hinduism</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Buddhism_in_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Buddhism in Indonesia (page does not exist)">Buddhism</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Confucianism_in_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Confucianism in Indonesia (page does not exist)">Confucianism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Yang_159-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Yang-159">[159]</a></sup> Indonesia is the world's most populous Muslim-majority nation, at 87.2%  in 2010, with the majority being <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nondenominational_Muslims&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nondenominational Muslims (page does not exist)">nondenominational Muslims</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-sp2010_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sp2010-161">[161]</a></sup> On 21 May 2011 the Indonesian <a href="/wiki/Sunni" title="Sunni" class="mw-redirect">Sunni</a>-<a href="/w/index.php?title=Shia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shia (page does not exist)">Shia</a> Council (MUHSIN) was established. The council aims to hold gatherings, dialogues and social activities. It was an answer to violence committed in the name of religion.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[162]</a></sup> 9% of the population was Christian, 3% Hindu, and 2% Buddhist or other. Most Indonesian <a href="/wiki/Hindus" title="Hindus" class="mw-redirect">Hindus</a> are <a href="/wiki/Balinese_people" title="Balinese people">Balinese</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-OEYBALI_163-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OEYBALI-163">[163]</a></sup> and most Buddhists in modern-day Indonesia are ethnic Chinese.<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[164]</a></sup> Though now minority religions, Hinduism and Buddhism remain defining influences in <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Indonesia" title="Culture of Indonesia">Indonesian culture</a>. Islam was first adopted by Indonesians in northern Sumatra in the 13th century, through the influence of traders, and became the country's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spread_of_Islam_in_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Spread of Islam in Indonesia (page does not exist)">dominant religion</a> by the 16th century.<sup id="cite_ref-csi_165-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-csi-165">[165]</a></sup> Roman Catholicism was brought to Indonesia by early Portuguese colonialists and missionaries,<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[166]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[167]</a></sup> and the Protestant denominations are largely a result of Dutch <a href="/wiki/Calvinist" title="Calvinist" class="mw-redirect">Calvinist</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lutheran" title="Lutheran" class="mw-redirect">Lutheran</a> missionary efforts during the country's colonial period.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[168]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[169]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[170]</a></sup> A large proportion of Indonesians—such as the Javanese <i><a href="/wiki/Abangan" title="Abangan">abangan</a></i>, Balinese <a href="/wiki/Hindus" title="Hindus" class="mw-redirect">Hindus</a>, and Dayak Christians—practice a less <a href="/wiki/Orthodoxy" title="Orthodoxy">orthodox</a>, <a href="/wiki/Syncretism" title="Syncretism">syncretic</a> form of their religion, which draws on local customs and beliefs.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[171]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Wayang_Pandawa.jpg" title="File:Wayang Pandawa.jpg">File:Wayang Pandawa.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Wayang_Kulit" title="Wayang Kulit" class="mw-redirect">Wayang Kulit</a> (shadow puppet) in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wayang_Purwa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wayang Purwa (page does not exist)">Wayang Purwa</a> type, depicting five <a href="/wiki/Pandava" title="Pandava">Pandava</a>, from left to right: <a href="/wiki/Bhima" title="Bhima">Bhima</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arjuna" title="Arjuna">Arjuna</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yudhishtira" title="Yudhishtira" class="mw-redirect">Yudhishtira</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nakula" title="Nakula">Nakula</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sahadeva" title="Sahadeva">Sahadeva</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indonesia_Museum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indonesia Museum (page does not exist)">Indonesia Museum</a>, Jakarta.</div></div></div>
<p>Indonesia has about 300 ethnic groups, each with cultural identities developed over centuries, and influenced by Indian, Arabic, Chinese, and European sources. Traditional Javanese and Balinese dances, for example, contain aspects of Hindu culture and mythology, as do <i><a href="/wiki/Wayang_kulit" title="Wayang kulit" class="mw-redirect">wayang kulit</a></i> (shadow puppet) performances. Textiles such as <a href="/wiki/Batik" title="Batik">batik</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ikat" title="Ikat">ikat</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ulos&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ulos (page does not exist)">ulos</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Songket&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Songket (page does not exist)">songket</a> are created across Indonesia in styles that vary by region. The most dominant influences on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indonesian_architecture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indonesian architecture (page does not exist)">Indonesian architecture</a> have traditionally been <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_architecture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indian architecture (page does not exist)">Indian</a>; however, Chinese, Arab, and European architectural influences have been significant.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Sport_in_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sport in Indonesia (page does not exist)">Sports in Indonesia</a> are generally male-orientated and spectator sports are often associated with illegal gambling.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[172]</a></sup> The most popular sports are badminton and <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">football</a>. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indonesia_national_badminton_team&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indonesia national badminton team (page does not exist)">Indonesian players</a> have won the <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Cup" title="Thomas Cup">Thomas Cup</a> (the world team championship of men's badminton) thirteen of the twenty-six times that it has been held since 1949, as well as numerous Olympic medals since the sport gained full Olympic status in 1992. Its women have won the <a href="/wiki/Uber_Cup" title="Uber Cup">Uber Cup</a>, the female equivalent of the Thomas Cup, twice, in <a href="/w/index.php?title=1994_Uber_Cup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1994 Uber Cup (page does not exist)">1994</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=1996_Uber_Cup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1996 Uber Cup (page does not exist)">1996</a>. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Liga_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Liga Indonesia (page does not exist)">Liga Indonesia</a> is the country's premier football club league. Traditional sports include <i><a href="/wiki/Sepak_takraw" title="Sepak takraw">sepak takraw</a></i>, and bull racing in Madura. In areas with a history of tribal warfare, mock fighting contests are held, such as <i>caci</i> in <a href="/wiki/Flores" title="Flores">Flores</a> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Pasola&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pasola (page does not exist)">pasola</a></i> in <a href="/wiki/Sumba" title="Sumba">Sumba</a>. <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Pencak_Silat&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pencak Silat (page does not exist)">Pencak Silat</a></i> is an Indonesian martial art.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Food_Sundanese_Restaurant,_Jakarta.jpg" title="File:Food Sundanese Restaurant, Jakarta.jpg">File:Food Sundanese Restaurant, Jakarta.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A selection of Indonesian food, including roasted fish, <i>nasi timbel</i> (rice wrapped in banana leaf), <i><a href="/wiki/Sambal" title="Sambal">sambal</a></i>, fried <i><a href="/wiki/Tempeh" title="Tempeh">tempeh</a></i> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tofu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tofu (page does not exist)">tofu</a>, and <i>sayur asem</i>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Indonesian_cuisine" title="Indonesian cuisine">Indonesian cuisine</a> varies by region and is based on Chinese, European, Middle Eastern, and Indian precedents.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[173]</a></sup> Rice is the main <a href="/wiki/Staple_food" title="Staple food">staple food</a> and is served with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Side_dish&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Side dish (page does not exist)">side dishes</a> of meat and vegetables. Spices (notably chili), <a href="/wiki/Coconut_milk" title="Coconut milk">coconut milk</a>, fish and chicken are fundamental ingredients.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[174]</a></sup> Indonesian traditional music includes <i><a href="/wiki/Gamelan" title="Gamelan">gamelan</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kroncong&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kroncong (page does not exist)">keroncong</a></i>. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cinema_of_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cinema of Indonesia (page does not exist)">Indonesian film industry's</a> popularity peaked in the 1980s and dominated cinemas in Indonesia,<sup id="cite_ref-kompasmovies_175-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kompasmovies-175">[175]</a></sup> although it declined significantly in the early 1990s.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[176]</a></sup> Between 2000 and 2005, the number of Indonesian films released each year has steadily increased.<sup id="cite_ref-kompasmovies_175-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kompasmovies-175">[175]</a></sup>
</p><p>The oldest evidence of writing in Indonesia is a series of <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a> inscriptions dated to the 5th century. Important figures in modern Indonesian literature include: Dutch author <a href="/wiki/Multatuli" title="Multatuli">Multatuli</a>, who criticized treatment of the Indonesians under Dutch colonial rule; Sumatrans <a href="/w/index.php?title=Muhammad_Yamin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Muhammad Yamin (page does not exist)">Muhammad Yamin</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hamka&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hamka (page does not exist)">Hamka</a>, who were influential pre-independence nationalist writers and politicians;<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[177]</a></sup> and proletarian writer <a href="/wiki/Pramoedya_Ananta_Toer" title="Pramoedya Ananta Toer">Pramoedya Ananta Toer</a>, Indonesia's most famous novelist.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[178]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup> Many of Indonesia's peoples have strongly rooted <a href="/wiki/Oral_tradition" title="Oral tradition">oral traditions</a>, which help to define and preserve their cultural identities.<sup id="cite_ref-UNESCO_Jakarta.2C_Indonesia_180-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNESCO_Jakarta.2C_Indonesia-180">[180]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Media_of_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Media of Indonesia (page does not exist)">Media</a> freedom in Indonesia increased considerably after the end of President Suharto's rule, during which the now-defunct Ministry of Information monitored and controlled domestic media, and restricted foreign media.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[181]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Television" title="Television">TV</a> market includes ten national commercial networks, and provincial networks that compete with public <a href="/w/index.php?title=TVRI&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="TVRI (page does not exist)">TVRI</a>. Private radio stations carry their own news bulletins and foreign broadcasters supply programs. At a reported 25 million users in 2008,<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup> Internet usage was estimated at 12.5% in September 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[183]</a></sup> More than 30 million cell phones are sold in Indonesia each year, and 27% of them are local brands.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[184]</a></sup>
</p>

Cooperation (page does not exist)">Member states of the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation</a></li><li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Category:Member_states_of_the_United_Nations&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Category:Member states of the United Nations (page does not exist)">Member states of the United Nations</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Category:Republics" title="Category:Republics">Republics</a></li><li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Category:States_and_territories_established_in_1949&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Category:States and territories established in 1949 (page does not exist)">States and territories established in 1949</a></li></ul></div></div>												<div class="visualClear"></div>
							</div>
		</div>
